data.ans: The ability of carbon to form bonds with other carbon atoms.
The ability of carbon to form four covalent bonds.
Compounds containing only carbon and hydrogen.
Hydrocarbons with single bonds between carbon atoms (alkanes).
Hydrocarbons with double or triple bonds between carbon atoms (alkenes and alkynes).
A saturated hydrocarbon with the general formula CnH2n+2.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon with a double bond and the general formula CnH2n.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon with a triple bond and the general formula CnH2n-2.
Compounds with the same molecular formula but different structural formulas.
An atom or group of atoms that determines the chemical properties of a compound.

data.que: Give an example of a functional group.
data.ans: -OH (alcohol)
A series of compounds with the same functional group and similar chemical properties.
The process of making soap by reacting a fat or oil with a base.
Sodium or potassium salts of long-chain carboxylic acids.
Ammonium or sulfonate salts of long-chain carboxylic acids.
The reaction between a carboxylic acid and an alcohol to form an ester.
Burning a substance in the presence of oxygen to produce heat and light.
Addition of oxygen or removal of hydrogen.
A reaction in which atoms add to a multiple bond.
A reaction in which one atom or group is replaced by another.
Addition of hydrogen to an unsaturated hydrocarbon to make it saturated.
Ethanol made unfit for drinking by adding methanol.
Different forms of the same element having different physical properties.

data.que: Give an example of an allotrope of carbon.
data.ans: Diamond
An aggregate of surfactant molecules dispersed in a liquid colloid.
An organic acid containing a carboxyl group (-COOH).
